Tuning the electronic structure and hydrophilicity of Prussian-blue type catalysts by incorporation of alklypyrazinium bromides, for enhanced activity Liji Liu a Simon Tricard b Xuhong Peng Investigation a Yunhong Chen Investigation a Hongchen Liu Investigation a Ganping Wang Data curation a Jian Fang Data curation a ⁎ Jihua Zhao Resources Data curation a ⁎ a Key Laboratory of Advanced Catalysis of Gansu Province, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineerin, Lanzhou University, Lanzhou, Gansu 730000, PR China Key Laboratory of Advanced Catalysis of Gansu Province, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineerin, Lanzhou University Lanzhou Gansu 730000 PR China Key Laboratory of Advanced Catalysis of Gansu Province, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineerin, Lanzhou University, Lanzhou, Gansu 730000, PR China b Laboratoire de Physique et Chimie de Nano-Objets, INSA, CNRS, Université de Toulouse, 135 avenue de Rangueil, 31077 Toulouse, France Laboratoire de Physique et Chimie de Nano-Objets, INSA, CNRS, Université de Toulouse 135 avenue de Rangueil Toulouse 31077 France Laboratoire de Physique et Chimie de Nano-Objets, INSA, CNRS, Université de Toulouse, 135 avenue de Rangueil, 31077 Toulouse, France ⁎ Corresponding authors. Prussian blue (PB) type material, a historical metal coordination material, is widely used in batteries, catalyst, and for energy storage. However, the scarcity of active sites and its immutable structure limit further applications. Herein, we propose a ligand substitution strategy to tune the electronic structure and hydrophilicity of the PB-type material, involving Fe(CN)5 as a cyanide precursor, to catalyze epoxidation of olefins. The catalytic performance can be significantly promoted for styrene oxide in the presence of a CoFe PB analog that includes decylpyrazinium bromide (named CoFe-10). Kinetic studies on styrene epoxidation with CoFe-10 show a low activation energy of 27.2 kJ/mol. In addition, mechanistic investigation, coupled to electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) measurements, suggests that the CoOOC(CH3)3 adduct is the reactive species for epoxidation of styrene. This study provides an effective strategy to synthesize unprecedented PB-type material and extend its application. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords PB-type material Ligand substitution Epoxidation Styrene oxide Hydrophobicity Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Highly active and selective epoxidation of CC double bonds has a wide application in organic synthetic chemistry[1–4], as it provides a way to introduce oxygen-containing three-membered rings for nucleophilic attacks. Meanwhile, due to the lack of functional groups and to easy access, the terminal olefins are susceptible to over-oxidize to aldehydes and acid as a by-product. Therefore, the highly selective epoxidation of terminal olefins is still a challenge. Styrene oxide (SO), a platform intermediate in organic synthesis, plays an important role in the fields of medicine, perfume and antiseptic[5–8]. At present, industrial production of SO uses the mainstream halohydrin method, but its by-product, oxyhalide, seriously corrodes equipment. In addition, styrene is easily over-oxidized to benzaldehyde and benzoic acid during the epoxidation process. Inspired by the advantages of mainstream heterogeneous catalyst systems[8], including facile separation, productivity and recyclability, constructing a suitable heterogeneous catalyst that can effectively improve reaction selectivity is fundamentally and practically necessary. At present, many heterogeneous catalysts for styrene epoxidation have been developed, including noble metals[2,9–14], metal oxides[6,15–24], and MOF materials[25–31]. Furthermore, recent reports have shown that the hydrophobicity and electronic structure of the catalyst play an important role in epoxidation reactions. For example, Shi et al. developed a radical copolymerization method with bis-vinylimidazolium salt and alkylfunctionalized ionic liquids to synthesis mesoporous poly-ionic liquids catalyst for epoxidation of cis-cyclooctene and tuned the hydrophobicity of catalyst to get higher catalytic performance by changing the molar ratios between the components[32]. On another hand, Xiong et al. applied an atomic layer deposition technology (ALD) to prepare CoOx/Al2O3/Pt catalysts and found that hydrogen spillover happening in Pt nanoparticles tuned the electronic structure of catalysts. Hence, the reaction selectivity can be improved from 76% to 94% under hydrogen atmosphere, compared to that in air[24]. Prussian blue, which is the first synthetic coordination compound reported in human history, has a long history of development. Its crystal structure was resolved as a face-centered cubic (fcc) unit cell in which FeIII and FeII are alternately bridged by cyano ligands. At the same time, the iron species can be replaced by other transition metals, such as manganese, nickel and cobalt, while the basic fcc crystal structure is maintained, resulting in Prussian blue analogues (PBA)[33,34]. PBA are widely used in fields such as batteries[34–36], sensors[37], biomedicine and water splitting[38–41], energy storage[42], etc. However, further progresses are needed in the field of PBA catalysis, especial in the CC catalytic reaction. A particular point of interest stems from the fact that the metals on the native PBA are all cyano-coordinated, resulting in a small proportion of available coordination sites, which are only located on the outer metal. Another essential concern is its changeless structure. Recently, PB-type material synthesized with the amminopentacyanoferrate complex (Na3[Fe(CN)5NH3]•3 H2O) as a raw materials is of great interest since its amino group can be substituted by coordination to other group. For example, Ghobadi et al. introduced 5,10,15,20-tetra(4-pyridyl)- 21 H,23 H-porphyrin (TPyP) and Janus green B into Na3[Fe(CN)5NH3]•3 H2O through ligand substitution and used it as a precursor to synthesize a dye-sensitized electrode with a Prussian blue structure, which showed significant catalytic ability and suppress of crystallinity[43,44]. Based on this, PB-type material with Na3[Fe(CN)5NH3]•3 H2O as precursors may be designed and applied as a new type of catalyst for styrene epoxidation. Hence, in order to enhance the catalytic performance of PBA on styrene epoxidation, it is necessary to reduce the crystallinity, adjust the hydrophilicity and regulate the electronic structure of the as-prepared catalyst. In this study, we report a ligand substitution to synthesize PB-type catalyst, for styrene epoxidation. Styrene conversion up to 82% was achieved with 75% of selectivity for styrene oxide in optimized conditions with CoFe-10 as catalyst. Meanwhile, the structure of the catalysts was characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM). Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) gave information on the electronic structure of catalyst. Finally, kinetic studies, EPR and Density functional theory (DFT) were performed to further clarify the catalytic mechanism and a plausible way for styrene oxide and benzaldehyde is established. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals and reagents All chemicals were used as received without further purification. All bromoalkane, N,N-dimethylformamide(DMF), pyrazine and tert-butylhydroperoxyde(TBHP) (70% in water) were purchased from Shanghai Macklin Chemistry Co., Ltd., China. Sodium nitroferricyanide was purchased from Tianjin Xiensi Chemistry Co., Ltd., China. Mn(CH3COO)2, Fe(CH3COO)2 and Ni(CH3COO)2 were obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. Co (CH3COO)2 was acquired from Tianjin GuanFu Fine Chemical Research Institute. Cu (CH3COO)2 was purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology. 2.2 Synthesis of Na3[Fe(CN)5NH3]•3 H2O The complex was synthesized following procedures from previous report, with slight modifications[43,44]. Ice bath was used in the whole experiment procedure. Briefly, 3.0 g of Na3[Fe(CN)5NO]•2 H2O was dissolved in 5 mL of water with 1.5 g of NaOH under constant stirring. After 30 min, 15 mL of cold NH4OH solution was dropped to the mixture and the color of mixture was changed from reddish to brownish. The mixture was continued stirring for 4 h and put in the fridge overnight. Then, the sample was vacuum filtered and washed with ethanol. Finally, the powder was dried in vacuum oven at 60 ℃ till constant mass. 2.3 Synthesis of the alkylpyrazinium bromides The preparation of alkylpyrazinium bromides was performed according to a previous report with slight modifications[45]. Briefly, 6 mmol of bromoalkane was added to 4 equimolar excess of pyrazine in 2 mL N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF). Then, the mixture was heated to 50 ℃ and stirred for 2 days in airtight condition. Next, the product was precipitated with 15 mL of cold diethyl ether, vacuum filtered and washed with ethanol. The product was dried in vacuum dryer containing phosphorus pentoxide. 2.4 Synthesis of CoFe-alklypyrazinium bromides 0.375 mmol of alkylpyrazinium bromides were first dissolved in 40 mL of water. 10 mL of Na3[Fe(CN)5NH3]•3 H2O solution was added dropwise to the resulting solution. After 2 h, 25 mL of Co(CH3COO)2 solution was dropped to the mixture. The precipitation appeared immediately when Co(CH3COO)2 was added. The mixture was aged 2 days to react completely. The precipitation was collected via centrifugation and washed with water three times. Finally, the powder was dried under vacuum oven at 60 ℃ to obtain the product and denoted as CoFe-8, CoFe-10, CoFe-12, CoFe-14, according to the alkypyrazinium bromides, like octylpyrazinium bromide, decylpyrazinium bromide, dodecylpyrazinium bromide, tetradecylpyrazinium bromide respectively. For MFe PBA (M = Mn, Fe, Ni, Cu) with dodecylpyrazinium bromide, the process of preparation was similar with that of CoFe-10 and catalysts were denoted as MnFe-10, FeFe-10, NiFe-10, CuFe-10, respectively. 2.5 Synthesis of CoFe PBA In brief, trisodium citrate dihydrate (0.25 mmol) and cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (0.25 mmol) were dissolved in water (25 mL). Citrate dihydrate (0.25 mmol) and potassium ferricyanide (0.25 mmol) were dissolved in water (25 mL). The solution of cobalt nitrate was dropped to the potassium ferricyanide solution and aged 2 days to react completely. The precipitation was collected via centrifugation and washed with water three times. Finally, the powder was dried under vacuum oven at 60 ℃ to obtain the product. 2.6 Characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) images were acquired from 10 ° to 80 ° on a MiniFlex600 diffractometer with Cu Ka radiation. Thermogravimetry (TG) curves were obtained on HCT-2 from 30 ℃ to 800 ℃ with five degree per minute in air. The styrene conversion and selectivity of styrene oxide was analyzed on 450 Gas chromatography (Varian) with HP-5 column. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Shimadzu Axis Supra) was conducted to explore the surface oxidation state of the elements. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) curves were gained on NEXUS 670. SEM images were captured by a S-4800 FEG at acceleration voltages of 40 kV and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained by a Tecnai F30. N2-adsorption/desorption were carried out at 77 K in an ASAP 2020 analyzer, and the surface areas of the samples were calculated using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method. EPR spectra were collected with a Bruker ER200-SRC-10/12 spectrometer. Contact angle tests were acquired on a SCD-100. 2.7 Epoxidation of styrene In a typical styrene oxidation reaction, 1 mmol of styrene, 1.5 mmol of TBHP, 5 mg of catalysts and 2 mL DMF were added in a 10 mL glass flask with a reflux condenser. Then, the reaction mixture was heated to desired temperature in oil bath and stirred for 10 h and cooled to room temperature. The reaction mixture was centrifuged and liquid product was analyzed by gas chromatograph-mass spectrometer (GC-MS) and by gas chromatograph (GC) with m-xylene as an internal standard. For the stability test, the catalysts were recovered by centrifugation from the reaction mixture, then washed with ethanol and dried at room temperature in vacuum dryer containing phosphorus pentoxide before the following test. 2.8 DFT Calculation All the structure optimizations, and energy calculations were carried out with the VASP program (Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package)[46,47]. The Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional was used. Since CoFe PBA is a strongly correlated system, LDA+U calculations were undertaken to describe the electronic structure of Fe and Co atoms, which Ueff(Co) = 5.1 eV, Ueff(Fe) = 3.9 eV. For the optimization of unit cell, surfaces and adsorption states, the cutoff energy of plane-wave basis set was set to 450 eV. Structures were optimized until the forces were less than 0.05 eV/Å and the Monkhost-Pack method was used for the 3 * 2 * 1 Brillouin zone integration. And more computational details are displayed in Supplementary Information. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Material characterization The CoFe-X catalysts (X specifies the number of carbon atoms in the alkyl chain) were prepared by mixing alkylpyrazinium bromides with the amminopentacyanoferrate complex (Na3[Fe(CN)5NH3]•3 H2O) under stirring, and then reacted with the Co(CH3COO)2 in deionized water, as shown in Scheme 1. XRD measurements were performed to characterize the crystalline structure of the so-obtained samples ( Fig. 1(a)). The reference CoFe PBA was prepared and characterized for comparison. Its diffraction peaks are located at 17.3°, 24.4°, 34.8°, 39.1°, which can be assigned to the (200), (220), (400), (420) planes of a face-centered cubic structure (PDF#86–503). CoFe-X (X = 8, 10, 12, 14) prepared by introducing alkylpyrazinium bromides as ligands, however, only clearly display the diffraction peak at 17.3°, corresponding to the (200) plane. Other peaks corresponding to the (220) and (400) plans are at the limit of detection and the broad new peaks around 20° also note that CoFe-X (X = 8, 10, 12, 14) tend to be amorphous nature, indicating the crystallinity of the catalysts are obviously decreased by ligand substitution. Those results are consistent with previous reports that the crystallinity of the catalysts can be suppressed by changing the symmetry of the cyanide metal with ligand[43,48–50]. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was used to analyze the composition change of the as-prepared samples (Fig. 1(b)). It is found that there are two stages of weight loss in CoFe PBA. The first stage is mainly loss of water (30 ℃−140 ℃) and the second stage is the destruction and decomposition of the cyanide framework (220 ℃−280 ℃), then the mass increase slowly because of the oxidation of the metals. Meanwhile, the TGA of CoFe-X demonstrate three stages of weight loss. The first stage is the loss of water (30 ℃−140 ℃), the second stage is the destruction of the cyanide framework (150 ℃−230 ℃) and the third stage is the loss of alkylpyrazinium bromides group (250 ℃−370 ℃). Compared to CoFe PBA, CoFe-X have lower content of water due to the partial substitution by the ligand. In addition, the decomposition of the CoFe-X cyanide framework occurs at lower temperature, suggesting that the stability of the catalyst is decreased by introducing alkylpyrazinium bromides. This observation is consistent with its poor crystallinity confirmed by XRD. The third segment is the loss of the pyrazine alkyl chain ligand. As expected, the longer the alkyl chain, the higher decomposition temperature and the greater the proportion of weight loss is. To reveal the morphology of the catalysts, the SEM images of CoFe PBA and CoFe-X are shown in Fig. 2. It is clear that CoFe PBA are particles with a well-defined cube structure (Fig. 2a). On the contrary, Fig. 2(b-e) displaying SEM image of CoFe-8, CoFe-10, CoFe-12 and CoFe-14 respectively, demonstrating that the original cubic structure of PBA is destroyed and transformed into irregular particles made of aggregated smaller particles. In addition, tests of water contact angles show CoFe PBA has high hydrophilic properties with a contact angle of 26.4°, while the CoFe-X series tend to be hydrophobic, with an increase of the contact angle with the length of the alkyl chain. The contact angle of CoFe-8, CoFe-10, CoFe-12 and CoFe-14 are 85.5°, 86.5°, 87.2° and 92.2°, respectively ( Fig. 3). It is induced that the hydrophilicity of the catalyst can be tuned by changing the length of the alkyl chain of ligand. Fig. 4(a) displays the FT-IR spectra of the as-prepared catalysts. The wide peak at 3400 cm−1 and the single peak at 1650 cm−1 can be assigned to the stretching vibration and bending vibration of O-H bonds, which is ascribed to the low water content of the catalysts. Compared with CoFe PBA, the peaks at 2900 cm−1 and 2850 cm−1 in the CoFe-X compounds are attributed to the stretching vibration of the C-H bond. The relative proportion of these peaks increase with the length of the alkyl chains of alkylpyrazinium bromides. The strongest vibration of all samples, including CoFe PBA and CoFe-X, ranges from 2060 cm−1 to 2160 cm−1 (Fig. S1), and is attributed to the stretching vibration of CN[38,39,51]. The spectrum of CoFe PBA exhibits two intense and sharp bands at 2160 cm−1 and 2113 cm−1, which are attributed to a mixing of the stretching vibration modes of FeⅢ-CN-CoⅡ and FeⅡ-CN-CoⅢ. Intriguingly, the IR spectrum of CoFe-X show cyanide stretching vibrations at lower wavenumbers and exhibit two strong vibrations at 2081 cm−1 and 2098 cm−1, which attributed to a mixing of the stretching vibration modes of FeⅡ-CN-CoⅡ and FeⅡ-CN-CoⅢ. Such lower energy vibrations than CoFe may be due to the interaction between the π * antibonding orbital of the pyrazine ligand which increase of the electronic density on the Fe center enhances back donation to the antibonding orbitals of the cyanide ligands, and thus to weaker vibration of the CN bounds[52,53]. Meanwhile, the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy also confirm the coexistence of FeⅡ and FeⅢ in CoFe PBA, while the sole FeⅡ state in CoFe-X (Fig. S4), consisting with the FT-IR results. In addition, the proportion of the two cyanide vibration modes change with increasing the alkyl chain length of alkylpyrazinium bromides (Fig. S1b). This effect is attributed to the increasing electron attraction of the ligand to the metal as the carbon chain grows, thus reducing the electron cloud density and increasing the valence state of the metal. These results indicate that the substitution of the alkylpyrazinium bromides can adjust the coordination environment of CoFe and change the valence state of the metals. In addition, the electronic structure of the catalysts was investigated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and its full spectrum analysis in Fig. S3. Co, Fe, C, N and O elements can be ascertained in the as-prepared catalysts as expected. Fig. 4(b) display the XPS spectra of different catalysts in the Co 2p region, which is the active metal of CoFe PBA[54]. Two characteristic peaks for CoFe PBA are located at 779.0 eV and 794.3 eV and correspond to Co2p3/2 and Co2p1/2 respectively. The deconvolution of the peaks indicates the coexistence of Co2+ and Co3+. For CoFe-X, the two peaks for Co2p3/2 and Co2p1/2 shift to 778.0 eV and 793.6 eV. Meanwhile, the content ratios of Co3+/Co2+ for CoFe, CoFe-8, CoFe-10, CoFe-12 and CoFe-14 are 1.31, 0.94, 1.01, 1.03 and 1.05 respectively, indicating CoFe-X have lower oxidation state of Co species than that of CoFe PBA, which is consistent with the results of FT-IR. (Fig. 4(a)). Scheme 2. 3.2 Catalytic performance Before the compare of catalytic performance between different catalysts, CoFe-10 was selected as the catalyst to optimize reaction conditions like temperature, the molar ratio of TBHP to styrene and solvent. The best reaction condition is to react styrene with 1.5 equivalent of TBHP in DMF under 60 ℃ (see Fig. S6 and Fig. S7 and Table S1). Thus, this reaction condition is selected to investigate the effects of other factors affecting the catalyst performances and the catalytic performance of the as-prepared catalysts are summarized in Fig. 5(a). The conversion of styrene without catalyst is only 16% with no significant selectivity between benzaldehyde and styrene oxide, and other products are phenylacetaldehyde and benzoic acid. With CoFe PBA, a conversion of 47% and a selectivity of 63% in styrene oxide is obtain, which confirm that CoFe PBA can be used as a potential catalyst for epoxidation reaction. It is noteworthy that the catalytic performance can be further enhanced when CoFe-X (X = 8,10,12,14) are used and both conversion and selectivity of epoxidation are both higher than 73%. And CoFe-10 catalyst give the highest styrene conversion of 82% and the highest selectivity for styrene oxide of 75%. The excellent performance of CoFe-X catalysts may be attributed to more accessible active sites exposure on the particle with low crystallinity, the lower oxidation state of Co and a stronger interaction between catalysts and the reactants, due to the hydrophilicity introduced by the alkyl chains. In order to investigate the active sites of catalyst, N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and the distribution of pore diameter of CoFe PBA and CoFe-10 show in Fig. 6. And the specific surface areas and corresponding pore volumes of CoFe PBA and CoFe-10 are listed in Table 1. However, and counter-intuitively, CoFe PBA shows a higher BET surface area (478.7 m2/g) than CoFe-10 (37.8 m2/g), which imply ligand substitution can collapse the face-centered cubic structure of PBA and seal some pore units. Meanwhile, the adsorption capacity of CoFe PBA in the low and medium pressure regions is much higher than that of CoFe-10, demonstrating CoFe PBA is major composed of micropores which are mostly inaccessible during the reaction. And the distribution of pore dimeter confirm CoFe-10 has a larger average pore dimeter and pore volume than CoFe PBA, which benefits molecular diffusion and provides more accessible react sites during the epoxidation reaction. Moreover, lower oxidation state of metal species can improve the catalytic performance because they can have higher adsorption energy to stabilize the reaction intermediates with electrophilic oxygen species produced by oxidants according to previous report[24,55–59]. Thus, the lower oxidation state of the Co species in CoFe-X than in CoFe PBA may also be an essential component for better catalytic performance. To further investigate the effect of the active species of metal on catalytic performance, we select several transition metal with similar atomic radius to Co, like Mn, Fe, Ni and Cu, as N-coordinate metal to react with Na3[Fe(CN)5NH3]•3 H2O and decylpyrazinium bromide. Then MnFe-10, FeFe-10, NiFe-10 and CuFe-10 are obtained, respectively, and their catalytic performances are shown in Fig. 5(b). It appears that the catalytic performance on styrene epoxidation can be greatly influenced by just changing electrons number of d orbitals. The MnFe-10(d5) shows the lowest styrene conversion of 31% and moderate selectivity of 60% for styrene oxide. For CuFe-10(d9), a 34% conversion with no selectivity between benzaldehyde and styrene oxide are obtained. MFe-10 (M=Fe, Co, Ni) display relatively high selectivity for styrene oxide. Interestingly, metals with better catalytic properties for styrene oxide are metals apt to valence change (MII ⇌ MIII). Electron exchange between inner metal and outer metal could thus form redox pairs in catalytic process, which is beneficial for oxidation reactions[60–62]. In comparison, Fe and Co have stronger transmission capacity[63,64], and therefore show higher catalytic performance than Ni. In addition, Co shows a higher affinity than Fe in terms of oxygen binding capacity[65,66], and thus exhibits the highest styrene conversion. Recycling performance and substrates scope of the catalyst. Time-dependent experiment of styrene conversion and selectivity of styrene oxide ( Fig. 7(a)) was performed to inspect the process of epoxidation. The conversion of styrene increased gradually over time and reached 98% after 24 h. The SO selectivity increases in the first ten hours, because an induction period is required. It then slowly decreased, maybe due to SO isomerization into phenylacetaldehyde[6]. After recovery by centrifugation, CoFe-10 maintains selectivity for styrene oxide with no significant loss of conversion for at least 3 cycles ((Fig. 7(b)), which shows its excellent stability. Meanwhile, CoFe-10 was also used as a catalyst for epoxidation of various olefins in the same conditions ( Table 2). Several styrene analogues, like 4-methylstyrene, 4-chlorostyrene and 4-bromostyrene, were studied, and 91%, 75% and 86% of conversion were achieved, with 86%, 69% and 72% of selectivity for styrene oxide (entry 1–3), for other substrates like 2-Norbornylene and trans-stilbene, much higher selectivity for epoxides were obtained (entry 4 and 5). 3.3 Kinetics studies To further understand the epoxidation of styrene mechanism, kinetic studies were conducted to obtain the order of reaction, the apparent rate constant k and the apparent activation energy. Firstly, in order to investigate the order of epoxidation reaction of different components (styrene, TBHP), the epoxidation of styrene on CoFe-10 catalyst under styrene excess or TBHP excess were conducted respectively. As shown in Fig. S5(A), the conversion increased linearly as a function of the reaction time under an excess of styrene, demonstrating the zero-order dependence on the concentration of TBHP. On the contrary, the conversion increased dramatically at the initial stage of the reaction, and slowly at the end of the reaction under an excess TBHP (Fig. S5(B)), suggesting a non-zero-order dependence on the concentration of styrene. Intriguingly, the conversion versus time under a TBHP excess can fit well with a pseudo-first-order (Fig. S5(C)), demonstrating the reaction order of styrene in epoxidation is one, which is consistent with previous reports[6,15,16,67]. Compared with normal experimental conditions, the apparent rate constant k obtained under excess TBHP has no practical significance. So, the epoxidation of styrene with the CoFe-10 catalyst demonstrates that the data of conversion obtained from time-dependent experiment ( Fig. 8(a)) is also fitting well with pseudo-first-order model (Fig. 8(b)). The apparent rate constant k of different catalysts is investigated through first order rate formula: kt = − ln C C 0 where k represents the rate constant and t is the reaction time; C and C0 are the concentration of styrene at time t and the initial concentration of styrene, respectively. By substituting catalytic data obtained from different catalysts into first order rate formula, rate constant k can be calculated as 0.063, 0.142, 0.171, 0.161 and 0.139 h−1, for CoFe PBA, CoFe-8, CoFe-10, CoFe-12 and CoFe-14 respectively. It is noteworthy that CoFe-10 shows the highest rate constant, 0.171, which is 2.7 times of CoFe PBA. Furthermore, CoFe-10 was used as a catalyst at various temperatures to obtain the activation energy of epoxidation reaction from the graph of ln k versus 1000/RT. (Fig. 8(b)) The apparent activation energy is determined to be 27.2 kJ/mol. Such a low activation energy confirms that CoFe-10 has powerful competitiveness, compared with the previous reports, which are presented in Table S2.[6,15,16,57,67–69]. 3.4 Mechanism analysis To further investigate the mechanism of epoxidation reaction, some control experiments under different conditions were conducted and summarized in Table 3. Firstly, when 0.1 mmol 2,6-Ditertbutyl-4-methylphenol (BHT) was added in the reaction as a radical scavenger, the conversion of styrene decreased to 66% (entry 2). When the quantity of BHT increased to 2 mmol, only 12% of conversion was obtained (entry 3). Those results show that the epoxidation of styrene in the presence of TBHP as oxidant is under radical process. Hydroxyl radical (•OH) and •OC(CH3)3 can be accessed by the homolytic cleavage of O-O bond of TBHP under the reaction conditions. To verify the role of •OC(CH3)3 in the reaction, ditertiary butyl peroxide (DTBP) which can directly provide •OC(CH3)3 as sole radicals species through the homolytic cleavage was used instead of TBHP[70,71], as all other factor were unvaried (entry 4). A quite low styrene conversion, 5%, compared to the case of using TBHP (entry 1) was obtained, indicating that the reaction channel leaded by •OC(CH3)3 as sole radical can be negligible. In addition, there is not any conversion when styrene oxide is considered as a substrate for the reaction (entry 5), which shows that benzaldehyde cannot be obtained from styrene oxide under the reaction conditions. To characterize the main active species of epoxidation of styrene, electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) was conducted to monitor the formation of the radical species during the reaction. As shown in Fig. 9, there is no distinct peak signal without the TBHP. Oppositely, in the presence of TBHP, a sextuple peak assigned to the characteristic peak of DMPO--OOC(CH3)3 is observed, which origin from the homolytic cleavage of TBHP produced •OC(CH3)3, and it further reacted with one molecule of TBHP to from •OOC(CH3)3. Mechanism of styrene epoxidation by computing the possible adsorption intermediates. Thus, a plausible catalytic reaction mechanism and the Schematic energy profile for the epoxidation of styrene catalyst by CoFe PBA and CoFe-10 demonstrate (The number in parentheses represents the number of cycles) are shown in Fig. 10. The various adsorption intermediates are labelled ads-x. Firstly, the homolytic cleavage of oxygen-oxygen bond of TBHP and the form hydroxyl group (-OH) and oxygen tert-butyl group (-OtBu) adsorb in the metal center of catalyst, respectively. In this step, the low oxidation state of the metal is beneficial to the adsorption of electrophilic tert-butyl group on the metal and accelerate the reaction, which can support by the larger free energy change obtained on CoFe-10 (−2.43 eV) than CoFe PBA (−1.23 eV), leading the ads-1 intermediate get more stable on CoFe-10 than CoFe PBA. Then, the -OtBu group adsorb in the metal center reacts with the free TBHP to form the -OOtBu intermediate and the energy further decreases at ads-2 both of CoFe PBA and CoFe-10. Then, styrene reacts with -OOtBu on the surface and the styrene oxide is desorbed from the surface and the -OtBu intermediate is regenerate. The subsequent reaction to generate ads-3 on CoFe PBA, the free energy raises by 0.86 eV. While the pyrazine-modified CoFe-PBA does not show such increase in the catalytic reaction process, which led to a better conversion of the reactants into the target products. Meanwhile, the CoFe-10 demonstrate a more accessible energy change compared with CoFe PBA during the catalytic cycle. Another minor channel is the reaction of hydroxyl group (-OH) with TBHP to further form adsorb hydroperoxyl radicals (•OOH), as reported by Fu et al.[70]. In belief, the benzaldehyde channel through the hydroperoxyl group react with hydroxyl group to from Co-μ-peroxo and form a four-membered ring with styrene. Then, the carbon-carbon bond cleavage and benzaldehyde generate. And the by-products, phenylacetaldehyde and benzoic acid and phenylacetaldehyde, are produce from ring-opening of styrene oxide and the overoxidation of benzaldehyde, respectively. Therefore, the catalytic performance of the pyrazine-modified CoFe-PBA is stronger than that of the pristine CoFe PBA catalyst, which is consistent with the experimental phenomena we observed. 4 Conclusion In summary, we have reported a ligand substitution method to synthesize CoFe PB-type material containing alklypyrazinium bromides as a catalyst for the epoxidation of styrene in the presence of TBHP as oxidant. This method reduces the crystallinity and disintegrates the structure of PBA, providing more accessible mesoporous to improve the reaction performance. The contact angle test shows that the CoFe-X compounds have stronger hydrophobicity than the CoFe PBA, which may enhance the affinity of the organic substrate during the reaction process, thus improving the reaction activity. In addition, FT-IR and XPS demonstrated that the oxidation state of cobalt species of CoFe-X is lower than that of CoFe PBA, which is beneficial to the adsorption of active species on Co metal, providing a low apparent activation energy for epoxidation of styrene, thus improve the catalytic. Furthermore, a series of control experiments and EPR measurements were conducted to distinguish the mechanism of reaction, suggesting that the CoOOC(CH3)3 species is responsible for epoxidation of styrene. This report shows a controllable method of adjusting hydrophilicity and outer metal electron density for PBA by ligand substitution. It can be extended to other nitrogen-containing aromatic as bridging groups in different catalytic reactions and chemical environments, providing an accessible way for further exploring the properties of PB-type materials. coredata.dc:description: Prussian blue (PB) type material, a historical metal coordination material, is widely used in batteries, catalyst, and for energy storage. However, the scarcity of active sites and its immutable structure limit further applications. Herein, we propose a ligand substitution strategy to tune the electronic structure and hydrophilicity of the PB-type material, involving Fe(CN)5 as a cyanide precursor, to catalyze epoxidation of olefins. The catalytic performance can be significantly promoted for styrene oxide in the presence of a CoFe PB analog that includes decylpyrazinium bromide (named CoFe-10). Kinetic studies on styrene epoxidation with CoFe-10 show a low activation energy of 27.2 kJ/mol. In addition, mechanistic investigation, coupled to electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) measurements, suggests that the CoOOC(CH3)3 adduct is the reactive species for epoxidation of styrene. This study provides an effective strategy to synthesize unprecedented PB-type material and extend its application.
coredata.dc:title: Tuning the electronic structure and hydrophilicity of Prussian-blue type catalysts by incorporation of alklypyrazinium bromides, for enhanced activity
